_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cartersville Elevator Inc, Mason City, Iowa 50401

       Facilty Manager: Steve Weiner
       Facility Telephone: (641) 421-0880
    
       1: Facility policy - The owners, management, and employees of the Cartersville Elevator Mason City 
        facility are committed to safety and the prevention of accidential releases of anhydrous ammonia. This
        adheres to all Federal, State, and local laws involving anhydrous ammonia. Employees will work with
        all local fire and emergency departments to minimize impact of an accidental release of ammonia 
        should it occur.

       2: Facilty Information - Anhydrous ammonia is stored in an 18,000 gallon tank that can be filled to 85%.
        If tank is filled to capacity 95940 pounds of anhydrous ammonia can be stored. The anhydrous 
        ammonia is delivered by transport truck and used in the reaction process when combined with 
        railroad delivered super phosphric acid and water. This process creates a liquid fertilizer product 
        called ammonium phosphate solution ( 10-34-0 ) and heat. Evaporating the water in a tower with
        a fan that pulls air through the product as it passes through baffles cools the finished product.

        3: Worst Case Release Scenario would be the release of the entire contents of the storage tank. 
         This would be 95940 pounds in ten minutes. The distance to the toxic end point concentration 
         ( .14mg/L ) is 1.12 miles. This extends offsite and includes public receptors.
         The Alternative Release Scenerio involves release of anhydrous ammonia from a rupture in a 
         2-inch diameter line during transfer from storage to the reactor. This scenerio would release 11,900
         pounds in 2 minutese. Distance to toxic endpoint concentration ( .14mg/L ) is .56 miles.

        4: Accident Release Program - This facility complies with the EPA's accidental release prevention
         requirements as well as state and local regulations.

The written operating procedures generally 
         follow the imforamtion in the OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous 
         Ammonia" as well as the American National Standards Institute - "Safety Requirements for the Storage
         and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1". These procedures are reviewed and revised on
         a regular basis.

        5: Five Year Accident History - There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia
         at this site during the last five years.

        6: Emergency Response Program - This facility maintains a written emergency action plan to be
         followed in the event oif a problem.

         7: Planned Changes to Improve Safety - Evaluations of procedures and equipment are made 
          constantly and improvements are implemented as well.
